questions.question_text: In which situation should an Endpoint Detection and Response solution be chosen versus an Endpoint Protection Platform?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It's so obvious if you know the difference between EDR and EPP.
A. when there is a need to have more advanced detection capabilities

Selected Answer:A
What is the difference between an endpoint protection platform (EPP) and endpoint detection and
response (EDR)?
EDR focuses primarily on advanced threats that are designed to evade front-line defenses and
have successfully entered into the environment. An EPP focuses solely on prevention at the
perimeter. It is difficult, if not impossible, for an EPP to block 100 percent of threats. So in the
ideal case, an endpoint security solution deploys both EPP and EDR capabilities.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/endpoint-security/what-is-endpoint-detection-
response-
edr.html#:~:text=What%20is%20the%20difference%20between,on%20prevention%20at%20the

%20perimeter.

Selected Answer: A
Its A. EDR provide advanced capabilities as EPP provide your traditional protections.
Answer should be A

A

EDR focuses primarily on advanced threats that are designed to evade front-line defenses and have successfully entered into the environment. 

An EPP focuses solely on prevention at the perimeter.

Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR)is the next gen replacement of traditional anti-malware which was primarily signature based. EDR is centrally managed because it is practically run by crowd sourced AI. Having a firewall on the network wouldnt influence a decision between the two. Signature based Anti-malware is going bye-bye.

Traditional EPP
Advanced EDR
So A fits better

Correct answer is A: when there is a need to have more advanced detection capabilities.
https://www.esecurityplanet.com/endpoint/antivirus-vs-epp-vs-edr/#:~:text=Endpoint%20detection%20and%20response%20(EDR)%20represents%20the%20newest%20and%20most,advanced%20layer%20of%20endpoint%20protection.&text=Whereas%20EPP%20is%20a%20first,they%20can%20cause%20significant%20damage.

choices.C: when there is a need for traditional anti-malware detection
choices.A: when there is a need to have more advanced detection capabilities
choices.D: when there is no need to have the solution centrally managed
choices.B: when there is no firewall on the network

discussion.content:
The correct answers are A. RADIUS and C. DHCP.

Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) uses different probes to gather information about network endpoints for device profiling and authentication. Two of the probes used to gather attributes of connected endpoints are:

A. RADIUS: Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) is a network protocol that provides centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) management for devices that connect and use a network service. ISE can use RADIUS probes to gather endpoint attributes such as device type, operating system, and installed applications.

C. DHCP: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is a network protocol that enables devices to automatically obtain an IP address and network configuration settings from a DHCP server. ISE can use DHCP probes to gather endpoint attributes such as MAC address, hostname, and IP address.

Selected Answer: AC
The selected answer is correct.

questions.question_text: What are two reasons for implementing a multifactor authentication solution such as Cisco Duo Security provide to an organization? (Choose two.)

choices.B: identification and correction of application vulnerabilities before allowing access to resources
choices.A: single sign-on access to on-premises and cloud applications
choices.E: flexibility of different methods of 2FA such as phone callbacks, SMS passcodes, and push notifications
choices.C: secure access to on-premises and cloud applications
choices.D: integration with 802.1x security using native Microsoft Windows supplicant

questions.question_text: Which threat involves software being used to gain unauthorized access to a computer system?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D - Virus
https://www.techtarget.com/searchsecurity/definition/RAT-remote-access-Trojan

A RAT (remote access Trojan) is malware an attacker uses to gain full administrative privileges and remote control of a target computer.

Therefore virus is used to gain access for the target! select Virus is a correct option

D is correct

questions.question_text: What are the two most commonly used authentication factors in multifactor authentication? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
"Authentication credentials are called factors. There are three categories of factors:

‚Ä¢ Knowledge (something the user knows)
 --> authentication by knowledge would be a user providing a password, a personal identification number (PIN) code, or answering security questions.

‚Ä¢ Possession (something a user has)
 --> authentication by ownership or possession include the following: a one-time passcode, memory card, smartcard, and out-of-band communication.
The most common of the four is the one-time passcode sent to a device in the user‚Äôs possession.

‚Ä¢ Inherence (something the user is)"
--> authentication by characteristic authenticates the user based on some physical or behavioral characteristic, sometimes referred to as a biometric attribute. The most used physical or physiological characteristics are as follows:
‚Ä¢ Fingerprints
‚Ä¢ Face recognition
‚Ä¢ Retina and iris
‚Ä¢ Palm and hand geometry
‚Ä¢ Blood and vascular information
‚Ä¢ Voice recognition

CCNP / CCIE SCOR official cert guide by Omar Santos

Selected Answer: AD
agree with A & D

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are correct. B is not correct, time is not a factor in MFA

Selected Answer: AD
I'll go for biometric and knowledge factor : 
Something you know - (Knowledge - password)
Something you have - (No choices)
Something you are - (Biometric - fingerprint scanning or facial recognition or voice biometry)

Time-Based One-Time Passcodes

Some websites and online services let users protect their accounts with a mobile-generated passcode that must be manually entered and only works for a certain amount of time ‚Äî typically 30-60 seconds. Duo Mobile can generate these time-based one-time passcodes (TOTP) for all third-party sites, letting users keep all of their accounts in one app."

Passcodes aren‚Äôt a real hit with users, either: each code must be manually entered, which can be a nuisance"

discussion.content:
Something you are.
Something you know.
Correct, A and D.

Time is not a factor: OTP falls under ownership factor, according to the 350-701 official cert guide. 
According to the offial cert guide, Biometris IS a factor: Authentication by characteristric

AD is correct, according to the official cert guide: ccnp-and-ccie SCOR 350-701chapter 4 AAA and Identity management:
There are three categories of factors: knowledge (something the user knows), possession (something a user has), and inherence or characteristics (something the user is).
Authentication by knowledge is where the user provides a secret that is only known by him or her. An example of authentication by knowledge would be a user providing a password, a personal identification number (PIN) code, or answering security questions.
Examples of authentication by ownership or possession include the following: a one-time passcode, memory card, smartcard, and out-of-band communication
A system that uses authentication by characteristic authenticates the user based on some physical or behavioral characteristic, sometimes referred to as a biometric attribute. The most used physical or physiological characteristics are as follows: Fingerprints, Face recognition, Retina and iris, ... Examples of behavioral characteristics are as follows: Signature dynamic, Keystroke dynamic/pattern

(there are no biometric, confidentiality and encryption factors).
There are (factor and example):
Time(access in time range),
Knowledge (password),
Location (access from different locations),
Possession (token),
Inherence (fingerprints) factors:
https://duo.com/product/multi-factor-authentication-mfa/two-factor-authentication-2fa
two most commonly use MFA has to be biometric and knowledge

comments.content: Biometric not common? Face-id, touch-id and all the related technologies?

discussion.content: The answer is B (Time) and D (Knowledge). First of all the question asks "What are the two most COMMONLY used factors in multifactor authentication?" Knowlege for sure, and time is referring to a one-time verification code, and these are the two most common. Biometric is not common. From the Official Study Guide "Wtih multifactor authentication, accounts are protected by something you know (password) and something you have (one-time verification code provided to you)."

time factor might be referring to TOTP as mentioned below by JC1418. That is where you login with your username and password, then your receive a One Time Password by SMS or email, that is Time based in that it expires in a few minutes. In my experience, the most common are knowledge (passwords and pins), then token/possesion(atm cards, credit cards, rsa token fobs, token-apps), then time-based (described above), biometrics isnt that common outside of smartphones.

time factor? who uses that?
Cisco/DUO consider biometric under inheritance, but it's still the best answer for me

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-multi-factor-authentication.html#~how-mfa-works

What are examples of multi-factor authentication?
The most common example of MFA is the process for using an ATM at a bank. To gain access to their accounts, users must insert a bank card (a physical factor) and enter a PIN (a knowledge factor).

Another familiar example is the time-based one-time password (TOTP) method, used by financial institutions and other large enterprises to secure workflows, applications, and accounts. Upon requesting login, users are asked to provide a temporary passcode that has been sent via a text message, phone call, or email.
The answers are A,D
